[[File:Gonickommphone.jpg|right|thumb|350px|Larry Gonick's ''Commoners'']] '''Larry Gonick''' (born 1946) is a [[cartoonist]] best known for ''[[The Cartoon History of the Universe]]'', a history of the world in [[comic book]] form, which he published in installments from 1977 to 2009. He has also written ''The Cartoon History of the United States'', and he has adapted the format for a series of co-written guidebooks on other subjects, beginning with ''The Cartoon Guide to Genetics'' in 1983. The diversity of his interests, and the success with which his books have met, have together earned Gonick the distinction of being "the most well-known and respected of cartoonists who have applied their craft to unravelling the mysteries of science".<ref>''Drug Discovery Today,'' March 2005</ref>
==Early life == Gonick was born on August 24, 1946, in San Francisco, California. He studied mathematics at [[Harvard University]], receiving his bachelor's degree in 1967 and his master's degree in 1969.<ref name="DuncanSmith2013">{{cite book|last1=Duncan|first1=Randy|last2=Smith|first2=Matthew J|title=Icons of the American Comic Book: From Captain America to Wonder Woman, Volume 1|date=1 January 2013|isbn=9780313399237|page=306|url=http://www.abc-clio.com/ABC-CLIOCorporate/product.aspx?pc=A3699C|accessdate=2 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702131810/http://www.abc-clio.com/ABC-CLIOCorporate/product.aspx?pc=A3699C|archivedate=2 July 2016}}</ref>
==Comic strips and cartoons== From 1990 to 1997, Gonick penned a bimonthly "Science Classics" cartoon for the science magazine ''[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]]''. Each two-page comic discussed a recent scientific development, often one in interdisciplinary research.
During the 1994-95 academic year, Gonick was a Knight Science Journalism Fellow at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]].<ref>[http://ksj.mit.edu/users/profile/848 Larry Gonick | Knight Science Journalism Program at MIT] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222205022/http://ksj.mit.edu/users/profile/848 |date=2014-02-22 }}</ref>
In 1997, his 14-issue series, ''Candide in China,'' published on the [[World Wide Web]], described Chinese inventions.
He also used to write the ''[[Kokopelli & Company]]'' comic that appeared in the magazine ''[[Muse (children's magazine)|Muse]]''.
He drew the satirical, anti-corporate comic ''Commoners'' for ''Common Ground''<ref>[http://www.commongroundmag.com commongroundmag.com ''Common Ground'']</ref> and later explained: :Feeling alternately mournful and enraged about the shameless expropriation of public space, public enterprise, publicly held goods like the atmosphere, oceans, and rivers, not to mention roads, parks, sidewalks, genomes, and the broadcast spectrum—indeed the very idea of the common good—I decided to do something about it! Well, say something, anyway.<ref>[http://www.larrygonick.com/html/pub/commoners/com16.html#1 Larry Gonick Comic Strips: ''Commoners''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112120530/http://www.larrygonick.com/html/pub/commoners/com16.html |date=2009-11-12 }}</ref>
Between 2009 and 2011 Gonick drew a humorous webcomic entitled ''Raw Materials''<ref>[http://www.simple-talk.com/author/larry-gonick/ ''Raw Materials'']</ref> that deals with technology and business matters, especially database administration.
